Award.AwardTitle: Representations of Affine Hecke Algebras and Geometry of Shimura Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
People encounter symmetry in daily life: it appears in human faces, butterflies, snowflakes, etc. In mathematics and natural science, symmetry is abundant and takes many forms as well. A fascinating area of current mathematical study concerns Weyl groups, which are certain collections of symmetries obtained by compositions of reflexive symmetries that satisfy braid relations. The study of the structure of the Weyl groups plays a fundamental role in understanding representations of the much larger groups that describe the symmetries of physical systems and in the geometry of Shimura varieties, two central themes in modern mathematics. In this research, PI will study the symmetries of Weyl groups and their applications in representation theory and arithmetic geometry.

The principal investigator will use recent discoveries about Weyl groups to study the representations of affine Hecke algebras and the geometry of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties and Shimura varieties. Recently, the PI established a connection between the affine Hecke algebras and the affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties that provides a new bridge between representation theory and arithmetic geometry. In this project, the PI will systematically develop this idea and will apply it to the study of modular representations of affine Hecke algebras and the study of special fibers of Shimura varieties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is based on the interface between representation theory and arithmetic geometry. More precisely, in this project the PI studies representations of affine Hecke algebras and geometry of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties and Shimura varieties. Modular representation theory of affine Hecke algebras is an important area in representation theory and in the p-adic Langlands program. The geometry of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties and Shimura varieties is an important object in arithmetic geometry. Most of the problems in these areas are very hard due to the complexity of combinatorial, geometric, and representation-theoretic structure.

The recent work of the PI and his collaborators advanced considerably the knowledge of the combinatorics of affine Weyl groups. This provides a very powerful tool in the study of some problems in representation theory and arithmetic geometry. By combining the combinatorics of affine Weyl groups with other geometric and representation-theoretic techniques, the PI and his collaborators made several important contributions:

(1) In a sequel of the papers, the PI, together with his collaborators (D. Ciubotaru and J.-L. Kim), initiated the theory of cocenter of reductive p-adic groups, which combines techniques from the geometric side and Lie-theoretic side of the p-adic groups to study their representations. The PI introduced the Newton decomposition of the cocenter, which, among other applications, gives a proof of Howe's conjecture. We also established two important results on the mod-l representations: the trace Paley-Wiener theorem and abstract Selberg principle.

(2) In arithmetic geometry, the PI has made several progresses by combining geometry with combinatorics and representation theory. In a joint work with M. Rapoport (Bonn), we gave a systematic approach to several important stratification of the reduction of Shimura varieties with arbitrary parahoric level structure. In a joint work with R. Zhou (Harvard), we study the connected components of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties, which is a key ingredient in the proof of Langlands-Rapoport conjecture for certain cases. In a joint work with U. Goertz (Essen) and S. Nie (Chinese Academy of Science), we prove a Hodge-Newton decomposition on affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties corresponding to arbitrary parahoric subgroups, extending the previous work of Katz, Mantovan, Chen-Kisin-Viehmann, etc. on affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties corresponding to hyperspecial parahoric subgroups. We then give a systematic study of the cases where the basic loci of Shimura variety has simple geometric description.

The PI has presented my work in many conferences and seminars. The PI gave talks in the Current development of Mathematics conference jointly organized by Harvard and MIT in Nov. 2015 and at the international congress of mathematicians in Rio, Brazil in Aug. 2018. These conferences are among the major event in the mathematical society. The PI supervised PhD student and postdoc at University of Maryland. The PI organized a working seminar on representation theory during his visiting at IAS in the year 2016-2017.
